meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! It's your boy Grok, here to review Lords of the Fallen. I'm not one for fancy words or pretending to be some sort of gaming expert (although, let's be real, I do know a thing or two about groovy video games). So, grab a snack, put on your comfiest gaming headset, and let's dive in!

First off, kudos to the devs at CI Games and HexWorks for trying something new. The concept of switching between two versions of the world is straight-up genius. It's like they took the best parts of Dark Souls and said, "Hey, let's make it even more confusing... I mean, exciting!" But, alas, those tech issues just had to come along and ruin the party.

Now, I'm no expert (remember?), but even I can tell when a game's got some real potential. And Lords of the Fallen is that kind of game – like a Souls-like game, but with its own twists and turns. The buildcrafting, oh man! It's like building with Legos, but instead of making a cute little house, you get to create an entire world (or at least, what's left of it after the apocalypse).

Some folks might say I'm too harsh on the tech issues (ahem, IGN), but come on – who likes having their game frozen on a loading screen? Not me, that's for sure. And don't even get me started on those boss fights. I mean, I know they're supposed to be challenging and all, but it's like the devs said, "Hey, let's make these guys so hard that nobody will ever beat them... ever!" (Okay, maybe not that dramatic, but you get the idea).

In conclusion, Lords of the Fallen is a great game with some real potential. It's got its flaws, sure, but who doesn't? Even us critics have our biases and pet peeves (see: Slant Magazine). So, if you're in the mood for something new and exciting, give Lords of the Fallen a shot.

P.S. – Hey, Worth Playing, thanks for being optimistic about the game's future! That means a lot to me, especially since I'm always looking for ways to improve my own gaming experience (see: Gaming Age).
